channel.title: Using command-line parameters

item.title: Using command-line parameters
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

The tutorial contains many grammar mistakes and code errors. None of the code blocks you posted are valid classes and will spit out errors when compiling. As to the final application, it would not exactly list all of the files contained in the directory passed through command line. In order for it to list absolutely all of the sub-files, you need to call the method recursively whenever a directory is found.

Anyways, I would advise proof-reading your tutorial next time before posting it. Also, learn a bit more as to what you are talking about before going around posting tutorials about them.

Read full topic

item.title: Using command-line parameters
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[code]import java.nio.file.Path;
import java.nio.file.Paths;
import java.nio.file.Attributes;
import java.nio.file.BasicFileAttributes;

public class DirectoryLister {

public static void main(String[] argv) {
    if (args.length == 1) {
        Path path = Paths.get(argv[0]);
        if (path.exists()) {
            BasicFileAttributes attrs = Attributes.readBasicFileAttributes(path);
            if (attrs.isDirectory()) {
                for (Path subpath : path.newDirectoryStream()) {
                    System.out.println("Subpath: " + subpath);
                }
            } else {
                System.err.println("Path " + path + " is not a directory.");
            }
        } else {
            System.err.println("Path " + path + " does not exist.");
        }
    } else {
        System.err.println("Usage:\n\tjava " + DirectoryLister.getClass().getCanonicalName()
                             + " <directory>");
        System.err.println("Example:\n\tjava " + DirectoryLister.getClass().getCanonicalName()
                             + " ./src");
    }
}

}[/code]

Mine’s better!

Read full topic

item.title: Using command-line parameters
item.dc:creator: @_ikram _ikram
item.description:
@_ikram wrote:

Today i am going to teach you how to use command-line parameters, these are used in every java program there is:

public static void main(String[] args)

Alright, first i am going to show you what the args parameter of the main method is used for.
The [i]args parameter is basically an array of strings that let you accsess any command-line parametrs that are specified when a user runs a java program.

Algith, for example you run your server or any java program named “Ikram” from a command program like this:

C:/>java Ikram is cool

In this above case, the java program is passed 2 parameters: is & cool, you can acsess these paramters from the args array…

Alright im now going to explain the main method in the “ikram” class, suppose the method is written like this:

public static void main(String[] args)
{
         for (string s : args)
               System.out.printIn(s);

}

Therfore the program displays the following output on the console (cmd) when you run the command, it would look like this:

is
cool

so you would tell me why is this tut even needed, command-line parameters are very uselful in java programs that work with files, they are used as a way to pass pathnames to the program. Most server use Command-line parameters aswell.

Here’s a program i found that lists all the files in a directory passed to the program as a parameter:


 import  java.io.*;

public class ListDirectory
{

    public statis void main(String[] args)
    {
            String path = args[0];
            File dir = new File(path);
            if (dir.isDirectory())
            {
                     File[] files = dir.listFile();
                     for (File f : files)
                     {
                          System.out.printIn(f.getName());
                      }
              }
              else
                   System.out.printIn("Not a directory noob.");
       }
}

Ikram

Read full topic
